newsitem.title: CYPRUS: Reduced Iranian flows cut Oct OPEC oil output - MEES.
newsitem.headline: Reduced Iranian flows cut Oct OPEC oil output - MEES.

text.p: OPEC crude output fell to 25.64 million barrels per day (bpd) in October mainly because of lower exports from Iran, the Middle East Economic Survey (MEES) newsletter reported on Monday.
Iran's output fell to 3.443 million bpd in October from 3.810 million bpd in September with exports, its lowest level since May, MEES reported.

"It is not easy to pinpoint the causes for such a sharp decline...a possible explanation might be found in upstream bottlenecks combined with month-to-month shifts in loading logistics," the Cyprus-based weekly said.
MEES estimated Iranian crude exports at 2.343 million bpd in October, down from 2.710 million the previous month.
Crude exports from onshore fields accounted for 1.913 million bpd and 430,000 bpd from offshore fields.
"The momentum of increasing Iranian supply to the Asia Pacific region has been maintained with deliveries to that area registering 1.078 million bpd," MEES said.
Venezuela remained the biggest quota violator, producing 3.1 million bpd versus its quota of 2.359 million bpd.
Nigerian crude output reached its highest level so far this year, averaging 2.14 million bpd in October.
OPEC ministers will meet in Vienna on November 27 to set the group's ceiling for at least the first half of 1997.
Leading OPEC ministers have already called for a roll-over of the group's current ceiling of 25.033 million bpd.
OPEC chairman and UAE acting oil minister Rakad bin Salem bin Rakad on Saturday said that ministers meeting in Vienna would also look into overproduction by member states.
